byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Nicola Clark and Alissa J. Rubin from Paris, Jack Ewing from Frankfurt, and Alison Smale from Berlin.
byline.original: By NICHOLAS KULISH and MELISSA EDDY

abstract: Dusseldorf, Germany, prosecutors say Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz had undergone treatment for suicidal tendencies prior to receiving his pilot's license; German law leaves it up to pilots to disclose their past mental health treatment to doctors who examine them to determine whether they are fit to fly; revelation has raised questions about whether doctors should be compelled to break confidentiality if patients display suicidal tendencies.
lead_paragraph: The co-pilot of the Germanwings jetliner that crashed in the French Alps had been treated before receiving his pilot’s license, officials said Monday.

headline.main: Germanwings Co-Pilot Was Treated for ‘Suicidal Tendencies,’ Authorities Say
headline.print_headline: Co-Pilot Treated for Tendencies Toward Suicide

snippet: The co-pilot of the Germanwings jetliner that crashed in the French Alps had been treated before receiving his pilot’s license, officials said Monday.
